text: RE: Microsoft stop messing with my people's task bar settings. My apologies -- in this instance a bit of both. In this case it just saddens me/frustrates me that someone is sitting in a meeting room thinking that in this era of phishing/quishing where we advise our staff to let us know of any changes in the behavior of their workstations, that re-enabling what someone turned off is a good thing and clearly was signed off on. That someone in a meeting room didn't think of the impact to help desk/users who suddenly go, what changed on my desktop, why is that back and reenabled when I didn't do anything but install updates? It reinforces to users that patches make changes they don't want. My communication to my own user base has gone to now rolling my eyes and saying "It's Microsoft". It's also a bit of my frustration that one has to look back to the prior month's preview updates to find changes documented. But agreed, we are here to manage and we should just deal with it. %4060a58536.com

metadata.topic: RE: Microsoft stop messing with my people's task bar settings.
